body: Shows all the selected charge types as "Type 1 + Type 2 + Type 3". The list shows which charge types were checked for the individual rule and how, by adding or subtracting, they are calculated together.

title: Posting rule
body: To manage the posting rules more effectively, the following functions are available:

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating an entire posting rule. To duplicate an entire posting rule set, e.g. all the individual rules defined within a posting rule set, click the Duplicate button on the left below the defined posting rule sets. A new posting rule set is created, and the code and name of the set are set with the text "-copy" at the end.

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating a group of rules. To duplicate a group of rules, e.g. all the individual rules with the same name / the same combination of transaction type and security characteristics, right-click the posting rule group and select "Duplicate". Define the combination of transaction type and security characteristic you want the copied rules to be applied to, and new rules are created with these new selections.

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating an individual rule. To duplicate an individual rule, right-click the individual rule and select "Duplicate". The selections of the copied rule are shown as default - define the combination of transaction type and security characteristic you want the copied rule to be applied to, and a new rule is created with these new selections.

title: Posting rule
body: Exporting posting rules in the XLS file . To export rules as an Excel file, choose the rule set, click and download the file.

title: Posting rule
body: Exporting posting rules in the CSV file. To export the rules in the CSV file that you can edit and import back in the system, choose the rule set, click Export , and download the file.

title: Posting rule
body: Importing posting rules in the CSV file. To import a CSV file with posting rules, click Add posting rule, fill in the Name, unique Code , and Account set fields, and click Import to upload the file. Note that the CSV file must contain the same account as in the selected account set.

title: Posting update
body: The Posting update section contains the following settings:

title: Posting update
body: Ask the user to confirm generation and updates of postings older than (excluding the date)

title: Posting update
body: A setting to prevent unintended changes in bookkeeping, for example, if the user edits an older transaction by mistake which can cause postings updates. If the postings that the user tries to update are older than the specified date, the system asks the user for confirmation.

title: Posting update
body: The system asks to confirm changes if the user modifies postings:

title: Posting update
body: Edits and saves a transaction in the Transaction window. The system asks the user to confirm the posting updates if they have configured posting generation when saving transactions in Preference (see General).

title: Posting update
body: Clicks Generate postings in the Transactions view.

title: Posting update
body: Creates a posting in the Transaction window or in the Bookkeeping view.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified posting currencies other than the portfolio currency. How are the values calculated?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Postings in the security currency use the transaction amounts where they are available. Wherever portfolio report items are used, the report FX is used to retrieve the security currency amount. Portfolio currency values are calculated using available report FX rates. For currencies specified other than the portfolio or security currency, available market FX rates are used to FX the security currency amounts to the corresponding posting currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified posting currencies other than portfolio currency. How is FX profit handled?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: FX profit considers the profit/loss between the security and the chosen currency as if it were the portfolio currency. This profit/loss is then converted with available rates to the system relative to the chosen currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified "Security types that get the purchase value from the cash purchase price of the account". What does this mean?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: For some security types, such as cash transactions, the definition of purchase price is not well defined. This setting allows you to set the purchase price for a cash-type transaction as the average purchase price of the cash in the account against which the transaction is booked. This price is the average FX rate on your cash transactions against your portfolio currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Example: The portfolio is in EUR. You have a USD account in which you deposited 100,000 USD at the rate of 1.25 EUR/USD. This leaves you with a purchase value of 80,000 EUR and an average purchase price of 0.8 EUR per USD. Any cash transactions that have a negative cash effect on this account are now assumed to have this as a purchased price. If you sell off the 100,000 USD on the account at a rate of 1.0 EUR/USD, the sold value in the portfolio currency is 100,000 EUR. From a portfolio perspective in EUR, this is a loss of 20,000 EUR.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Any purchase price and profit realized on transactions with this set on the security type should also be visible in Analytics+. For example, any purchase value of future cashflows should be booked from the corresponding cashflow in/out transactions and viewable in Analytics+.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified "Security types that get the purchase value from the cash purchase price of the account". Does this give me the true realized profit on FX spots/forwards?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: No. The setting gives you the realized profit against the account's average purchase price of cash. A true realized profit on a FX spot or forward is compared against the spot price at settlement and what you contracted at inception. It is also compared against the spot pair in all cases, whereas the average price is compared against the account and portfolio (not necessarily the same as the spot/forward pair).

title: Related links
body: Standard bookkeeping rules in FA User guide.

title: Preference - Content and translations
body: Content and translations preferences include relevant preferences for flexibly defining the texts, translations and formatting used for different languages. These preferences allow you to override the default date formats, number formats and texts used to show dates, numbers and texts on FA's user interface.

title: Analytics+ columns
body: You can configure custom columns for Analytics+, for example, based on security key figures or mathematical formulas. To learn about adding columns to Analytics+, see Configuring Analytics columns in Preferences in FA User guide.

title: Date and decimal formats
body: Date and decimal formats allow you to define different date and decimal formats to be used for different user interface languages.

title: Date and decimal formats
body: For example, instead of showing dates always with the default format of "dd.MM.yyyy", you can set dates to be shown in formats such as "yyyy-MM-dd" or "MM/dd/yyyy". For numbers, you can control how many decimals are shown with number formatting. For example, use "#,##0" not to show any decimals, "#,##0.00" to always show two decimals, or "#,##0.######" to show up to six decimals if there are decimals to show.

title: Key figures
body: Key figures are available as selectable columns in different search views. For example, you can store credit ratings as a key figure for securities, view the latest credit ratings in the Securities view, and search for securities with a certain credit rating. You can also configure a key figure to be available to a specific portfolio or security type and only allow users to select values for the key figure from a pre-defined list of options.

title: Key figures
body: For instructions on adding key figures and configuring them as columns in Analytics+, see in Add a column based on a key figure FA Developer.

title: Key figures
body: When adding a new key figure, you need to specify the following information:

title: Key figures
body: Select where you want to use this key figure - Select if the key figure is associated with contacts, portfolios, or securities. The key figure is available in the corresponding window. You can only select one option.

title: Key figures
body: Define the types you want this key figure to be available for - You can restrict the key figure visibility to certain types only. For example, the key figure can be visible to "customers" but not other types of contacts. Enter the type codes as comma-separated list (for example: BOND,FUND). If you don't restrict the key figure visibility, it is available to all contacts, portfolios, or securities.

title: Key figures
body: Code - A unique code for the key figure. Use only alphanumeric values (letters a-z and numbers 0-9, no spaces or special characters). The key figure code is used to identify the key figure and you can't modify it after saving.

title: Key figures
body: Name - A name for the key figure, used throughout the FA Platform.

title: Key figures
body: Value type - Select what values users can record with this key figure. The default type for key figure values is numbers (integers). Other options are integer (whole number), string (text), double (number), and boolean (true/false options).

title: Key figures
body: Allow users to enter values manually or to select from a pre-defined list - Select if users need to enter values manually by typing them or if there should be a dropdown list of available options to enter (see Enter key figure values manually or select from a pre-defined list).

title: Key figures
body: Define the values users can select - If you selected the option "Select values from a predefined list" for the previous setting, you need to define the options that users can choose from. Define the options on separate rows. If you leave the list empty, users can't select a value for the key figure. See Enter key figure values manually or select from a pre-defined list.

title: Enter key figure values manually or select from a pre-defined list
body: You can control user input for key figure values with the Allow users to enter values manually or select from a pre-defined list setting. If values can be entered manually, users see a free input field for a number or text (depending on the key figure value type). If values are selected from a pre-defined list, users see a dropdown list of options. When defining the pre-defined values, you have two options:

title: Number formats
body: Number formats

title: Number formats
body: Number formats allow you to set the decimal separator used in the system according to a language locale which consists of a language and a country. You can view the languages and locales in the system in Preference - General.

title: Number formats
body: To define the number format for a language, enter the language locale in its column. For example, if you enter the language locale "fi_FI" in the "Suomi" column, the system uses a comma as the decimal separator when the language is Finnish. If you leave the language column empty, the system uses the default decimal separator.

title: Profile definitions
body: You can define and maintain custom fields for contacts, portfolios, and securities using the profile definition preferences. Profile definitions determine the content and fields in custom tabs and allow you to control where and to whom the tabs are shown. These preferences are available from FA 3.8 onward.

title: Available profile definitions
body: The profile definitions are categorized as follows:

title: Available profile definitions
body: Contact - Profile definitions linked to contacts, available as tabs in the Contact window.

title: Available profile definitions
body: Other

title: Available profile definitions
body: Profile definitions not classified as "Contact", "Portfolio", or "Security". These profiles are not shown as custom tabs in main windows but used to define the content of, for example, custom designs in FA Front or the Design-based importer extension.

title: Available profile definitions
body: Profile definitions added before FA 3.8 not yet classified as "Contact", "Portfolio", or "Security" (see Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities).

title: Available profile definitions
body: Portfolio - Profile definitions linked to portfolios, available as tabs in the Portfolio window.

title: Available profile definitions
body: Security - Profile definitions linked to securities, available as tabs in the Security window.

title: General settings
body: You can manage profiles with a single form. The syntax is technical but the main controls are available separately. The most important input is validated when you save the form.

title: General settings
body: Code - A unique identifier for the profile. You can use the code to sort custom tabs in the corresponding window. Custom tabs are sorted alphabetically (available from FA 3.8 onward).

title: General settings
body: Name - The name of the profile, used as the tab title in the corresponding window.

title: General settings
body: Where you want to use this profile - Where the profile is shown. Select "Contact", "Portfolio", "Security", or "Other". Select "Other" if you are using the profile for custom designs in FA Front or the Design-based importer extension.

title: General settings
body: Type - What technical syntax is used to define the profile content. You can choose "FA Back (XML UI)" which only allows you to define custom tabs in FA Back, or "FA Back and FA Front (Vaadin design)" which also allows you to define custom designs for FA Front.

title: General settings
body: Restrict this profile to be shown to roles - Controls the visibility of the profile in FA Back based on specific user roles. Define the roles as a semi-colon separated list. If left empty, all users can see the profile. For example, "ADMIN;BO" shows the profile only to users with the "ADMIN" or "BO" role.

title: General settings
body: Define criteria for when this profile is shown - Controls the visibility of the profile in FA Back based on the characteristics of contacts, portfolios, or securities. Define the characteristics as a comma-separated list that should be matched for the profile to be shown. If left empty, the profile is always shown. For example, "“group=FUND,type=INV;ASSET,language.code=EN” shows the profile to portfolios of type "INV" or "ASSET" with language "EN" in the group "FUND".

title: General settings
body: Editor / Preview / Generated XML - Content of the profile. In the Editor tab, you can enter the technical profile definition syntax. The Preview tab generates a user interface preview of the profile. The Generated XML tab shows you the XML generated automatically based on the profile.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: The profile definition Code determines if the profile is linked to a contact, portfolio, or security (if the profile classification is "Other", this logic is backward-compatible from FA 3.8 onward):

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: If the code begins with "CONTACT.", the profile definition is linked to contacts.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: If the code begins with "PORTFOLIO.", the profile definition is linked to portfolios.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: If the code begins with "SECURITY.", the profile definition is linked to securities.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: You can link profile definitions to specific contacts, portfolios, or security types by adding the type code after the profile definition code. For example, a profile definition starting with "CONTACT.1." is linked to contacts of the "Customer" type, and a profile definition starting with "PORTFOLIO.INV." is linked to investment portfolios of the "INV" type.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: You can link contact profile definitions to specific contact subtypes by adding a semicolon and the subtype code to the profile definition code. For example, you can specify "CONTACT.1:FC" as the profile definition code. The profile is linked to contacts with the "Customer" type and fund companies (contact subtype) with the code "FC".

title: Defining the profile content
body: Use "Vaadin design" or "XML UI" syntax to define the profile content. For more information about defining profile content, see Profiles in FA Developer guide.

title: Texts
body: Texts allow you to override any texts visible in the user interface by defining them separately for different user interface languages. The overridden texts are applied both to FA Back and FA Front - whatever text you override, will be applied everywhere on the user interface.

title: Texts
body: Search for the default text or key, and override the text in the languages you want. For example, if you want to translate the texts within Analytics+, search with the code "analyticsPlus" and find the correct column with the name.

title: Texts
body: At the bottom, the Show only overridden texts / Show all texts button allows you to easily detect which formats or texts have been overridden.

title: Translations
body: Translations allow you to define translations to be used on the portfolio reports for the categorizations, classifications, and other configurations you have defined in Preference. The permanent translations of the reports, such as titles, headings, and columns, are translated and saved in the system. However, for example, security or transaction types used in the reports are set and defined in Preference and are not translated automatically: in order to be able to print fully translated reports, you need to define translations in Preference. In addition to reports, the translations are used when the language of the user interface is changed.

title: Translations
body: The preferences you can translate have been separated on different tabs. The information you can translate is divided into columns:

title: Translations
body: Code

title: Translations
body: The code of the preference you are translating, as defined in Preference.

title: Translations
body: Default

title: Translations
body: The default name of the preference you are translating, as defined in Preference. This is the text that will be used for your preference if you don't have any translations defined.

title: Translations
body: Languages

title: Translations
body: After the code and the default, the available languages are shown as a separate column, allowing you to define a different translation for each language. By default, the supported languages are English, Finnish, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian. Adding a corresponding language with the correct locale in the language preferences the allows you to define translations in that language.

title: Widgets
body: Widget preferences allow you to define widgets that you can select on your dashboard.

title: Preference - Taxation
body: In Preference → Taxation, you can configure preferences for tax types and default tax rates.

title: Default tax rates
body: Default tax rates are used to automatically fill in tax information when you run corporate actions or add transactions. In Taxation → Default tax rates, you can define default tax rates for different combinations of transaction type, security country or type, portfolio juridical form and tax country, and portfolio type and tags. A default tax rate only applies when all defined criteria are met.

title: Default tax rates
body: For example, you can define a default tax rate of 7,5% withholding tax for for all dividends on Finnish stocks which are recorded to portfolios owned by private persons in Finland.

title: Default tax rates
body: You can search existing default tax rates in the system using the search fields at the top of each column. You can also modify or delete an existing default tax rate by selecting it in the list.

title: Define a default tax rate
body: To add a new default tax rate, do the following:

title: Define a default tax rate
body: Click Add.

title: Define a default tax rate
body: Fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Default tax rate information.

title: Define a default tax rate
body: Click Save.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Default tax rates are defined with the following fields:

title: Default tax rate information
body: Transaction type*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Transaction type this default tax rate is used for (for example, buy, sell, or dividend).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security country*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security country this default tax rate is used for.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Juridical form*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio juridical form this default tax rate is used for.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tax country*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio tax country this default tax rate is used for.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security type

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security type this default tax rate is used for (if no security type is selected, the default tax type is used for all types of securities when other conditions are met).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security subtype

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security subtype this default tax rate is used for (if no security subtype is selected, the default tax type is used for all types of securities when other conditions are met).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tax rate

title: Default tax rate information
body: Default tax rate to use for the defined criteria combination.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tax type

title: Default tax rate information
body: Type of the default tax rate (tax types are defined in Preference - Tax types).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio type

title: Default tax rate information
body: Type of portfolios this default tax rate applies to. If left empty, the default tax rate applies to all portfolio types.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio tags

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tags a portfolio has to have for this default tax rate to apply (optional). If multiple tags are entered, the portfolio has to match them all.

title: Tax types
body: Tax types are used to determine the type of tax recorded for a transaction, for example, capital gains tax or VAT. The Transaction window has two fields for taxes, and tax types configured in Preference view can help you identify and categorize these taxes. Tax types are also used to define default tax rates for running corporate actions.

title: Tax types
body: You can view and modify tax types in Taxation → Tax types.

title: Define a tax type
body: To add a new tax type, do the following:

title: Define a tax type
body: Click Add tax type.

title: Define a tax type
body: Fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Tax type information.

title: Define a tax type
body: Click Save.

title: Tax type information
body: Tax types are defined with the following fields:

title: Tax type information
body: Code*

title: Tax type information
body: The individual tax type code that separates it from other tax types.

title: Tax type information
body: Name*

title: Tax type information
body: The name of the tax type. The name of the tax type is shown in the Transaction window.

title: Tax type information
body: Profit

title: Tax type information
body: The selection tells whether the tax type has a profit effect. The profit effect indicates whether the amount of this type of tax will have an effect on the portfolio's profit and whether the amount of this type of tax will be included in the position's purchase value. By default, the profit effect is not selected, and the tax will not have an effect on the portfolio's profit or will not be included in the portfolio's purchase value.

title: Tax type information
body: Cash

title: Tax type information
body: The selection tells whether the tax type has a cash effect. The cash effect determines whether this type of tax has an effect on the portfolio's cash, i.e. is the amount of the tax deposited to or withdrawn from the portfolio's account with the transaction. By default, the cash effect is selected, and the tax has the same effect on the portfolio's account as the transaction does. If not selected, only the net price of the transaction without the tax of this type would affect the portfolio's cash.

title: Top menu
body: All key functions are available for you in the top toolbar – you can find relevant functions structured as menus on the left, or ordered with descriptive icons on the right.

title: New
body: The New menu allows you to manually create something new into the system.

title: New
body: New report generates a new report from the Report window.

title: New
body: New contact creates a new contact in the Contact window.

title: New
body: New portfolio creates a new portfolio in the Portfolio window.

title: New
body: New security creates a new security in the Security window.

title: New
body: New transaction creates a new transaction in the Transaction window (choose the security type of the transaction from the menu - the available security types are listed in the order defined in Preferences - Security types).

title: New
body: New trade order creates a new trade order in the Trade order window (choose the security type of the trade order from the menu - the available security types are listed in the order defined in Preferences - Security types).

title: New
body: New corporate action creates a new corporate action in the Corporate action window.

title: New
body: New contract creates a new contract in the Contract window.

title: Tools
body: The Tools menu allows you to launch various kinds of standard and custom processes. The processes include:

title: Tools
body: Administering the FA system.

title: Tools
body: Creating coupons and expirations, paydowns, and securities from outside sources.

title: Tools
body: Launching fee calculations and monitoring processes.

title: Tools
body: Importing files and sending documents.

title: Tools
body: Creating contacts.

title: Tools
body: Realizing profits and losses on FX contracts.

title: Tools
body: Synchronizing the FA system.

title: Update
body: The Update menu allows you to recalculate portfolio report data for a selected portfolio or all portfolio and to show the status of ongoing report calculations. Clicking on an option in the Update menu produces a notification indicating what option was clicked.

title: Update
body: Clicks within the Update menu are audited: if a user clicks a menu item, the action is recorded in the audit logs with the message "User [username] clicked [name of menu item]". If a user launches recalculation for a selected group, customer, or portfolio, the audit log message is "User [username] clicked [name of the menu item] for group/customer/portfolio [id]”. Audit logs also show for which portfolios and from what date onward reports were recalculated. (Available from FA 3.9 onward).

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Typically, report data is set to be recalculated automatically (see Preference - Administration). The Update menu allows you to do recalculation manually, for example, if automatic recalculation was unsuccessful.

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Be careful when triggering a full report recalculation for all portfolios, because updating reports for all portfolios can take a long time and some functionalities become unavailable during the process.

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Recalculate all report data of the selected group / customer / portfolio. Recalculates all purchase lots (what is shown in FA) and the report data (what is shown in analytics and reports) for the whole history of the selected portfolios.

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Recalculate all report data of all portfolios. Recalculates all purchase lots (what is shown in FA) and report data (what is shown in analytics and reports) for the whole history of all portfolios in the system. This option prioritizes sub item recalculations over report item recalculations and first drops the report tables to not spend time on deleting individual entries from them and ensure critical FA Back functionalities are available first.

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Recalculate purchase lot and report data separately for all portfolios. Allows you to recalculate purchase lots (what is shown in FA) and report data (what is shown in analytics and reports) in two separate steps, so you can control what data to calculate. For example, you can calculate purchase lots first to ensure critical functions of the system are available as soon as possible, and calculate report data later. You can also only calculate report data, for example, if the purchase lots are up-to-date.

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Recalculate purchase lot data (sub items) for all portfolios. Recalculates all purchase lots for all portfolios. After purchase lots are updated, you can use the main features of FA Back, excluding functionality relying on analytics of report data.

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Recalculate report data (report items) for all portfolios. Recalculates all report data for all portfolios. After report data is updated, you can use FA Back functionalities relying on analytics or report data. Ensure that the purchase lots are up-to-date before updating report items.

title: Recalculate report data manually
body: Re-run the nightly report data update for all portfolios. Recalculates portfolio report data (what is shown in analytics and reports) for all active portfolios starting from the last report date until the current date. If portfolio reports are already up-to-date (there are reports for the current date), no recalculation is run.

title: Recalculate transaction effects manually
body: The Update menu allows you to recalculate transaction effects manually. This is only required if you change the effects of a transaction type in Preference → Transactions → Transaction types but don't click Update (see Preference - Transactions). For example, you can change the tax or cost effect from "adding" to "reducing", resulting in a different trade amount if taxes or costs are added instead of subtracted. After the transactions are "recalculated" (transaction trade amounts updated based on the effects change), the system recalculates the affected portfolio reports data.

title: Recalculate transaction effects manually
body: Be careful when triggering a full report recalculation for all portfolios, because updating reports for all portfolios can take a long time and some functionalities become unavailable during the process.

title: Recalculate transaction effects manually
body: Recalculate transaction effects of selected group / customer / portfolio. Recalculates the transaction effects of the selected portfolio for the changes made in transaction types (the trade amounts and cash flows of the transactions in the selected portfolios are re-calculated to take into account the changes made to transaction types).

title: Recalculate transaction effects manually
body: Recalculate transaction effects of all portfolios. Recalculates the transaction effects for all portfolios for the changes made in transaction types (the trade amounts and cash flows of the transactions in the all portfolios are re-calculated to take into account the changes made to transaction types).

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Market data connection is only available in the Update menu if you have enabled an external market price source for FA through a market data connector (see Market data connectors in FA Admin guide).

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: With the Market data connection menu items, you can fetch update codes and prices for securities with the "Active" status. Fetching market prices always triggers a report calculation to update the effect of the new market prices in your portfolios. This report calculation starts from the earliest market price received and affects all portfolios containing securities that receive an updated price.

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Get missing update codes. Uploads missing update codes from the external price source and saves them in the Update code 1-3 fields in the Security window. The system uploads and saves update codes for securities that don't already have an update code defined but have the "Active" status and a defined ISIN code. The ISIN is used to match the update code with the correct security. Note that some securities (for example, currencies) don't have valid ISIN codes, so you need to enter the update code manually.

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Get market prices. Fetches market prices for "Active" securities with a corresponding update code (if market data connection is enabled for Update code 2 / Close 2, prices are only fetched for securities that have the Update code 2 defined).

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Get market prices for past 7 days. Fetches all prices for the past 7 days, updating existing market prices*.

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Get market prices for past 30 days. Fetches all prices for the past 30 days, updating existing market prices*.

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Get market prices for past 365 days. Fetches all prices for the past 365 days, updating existing market prices*.

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Get market prices from [date]. Fetches all prices starting from the Earliest market price date configured in Preference - Administration (FA Back reference), updating existing market prices*.

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Get missing market prices. Fetches market prices for each security from the latest existing market price onward. The system goes through all securities with a corresponding update code, determines the latest available market price date for each security, and fetches new prices for that security from that date onward. If a security doesn't have existing market prices, they are fetched from the Earliest market price date configured in Preference - Administration (FA Back reference) onward. Depending on your existing market price history, prices might be fetched for different time periods for different securities, based on their latest available observation. This option allows you to fetch "prices that are newer than the newest observation already stored".

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: * Updating existing market prices means that if a market price entry already exists for the same date for a security, fetching the price again through the connector updates the market price in the relevant Close field. The system only updates market price entries received from the connector.

title: Upload market prices from external sources with market data connections
body: Example: A security has a price for 2.1.2019 with entries in the Manual and Close 2 fields. You fetch the market price again and include this date (using a market data connector linked to Update code 2 / Close 2). As a result, the value in Close 2 is updated to be the value received from the connector. The value in Manual stays the same.

title: Revaluate securities
body: Revaluate all securities is only available in the Update menu if you have the user role that permits revaluating securities.

title: Revaluate securities
body: The Revaluate all securities menu items allow you to recalculate the discount factors for a specific time period on all your securities that have the base type DISCOUNT and other relevant information. The system never calculates discount factors on a security before the beginning of the position or after the maturity date, and all calculations are done until the previous day.

title: Revaluate securities
body: Revaluating securities always triggers a report calculation to update the effect of the new values in your portfolios. The report calculation affects all portfolios containing securities that receive a new valuation. For more details on the revaluation menu items, see Valuation of forward cashflows.

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: The Show pending and ongoing calculations menu item allows you to view pending, ongoing, and failed report calculations. You can refresh the records, export the table as an XLSX file, or delete all records. By default, calculations are deleted automatically after 30 days.

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: The tabs Pending and ongoing and Failed provide the following information:

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Scheduled

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Date and time the report calculation was scheduled to take place.

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Update since

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Date from which onwards the data is calculated. For example, if the date is a week in the future, report calculations are run from that date onwards until the completion time.

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Type

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Report calculation type that distinguishes different report calculation jobs. "FULL-ALL" calculates positions and purchase lots for a portfolio's full history, "FULL" calculates positions for a portfolio's full history, "LATEST" calculates positions starting from a specific date, "SUB" only calculates purchase lots, and "REMOVE" removes report data for a portfolio.

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Portfolio ID

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Unique ID of a portfolio.

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: ID

title: Show status of portfolio report calculation
body: Report calculation ID.

title: Menu icons
body: The following options are available at the top right of the menu:

title: Menu icons
body: Click to select the language of the user interface (English, Finnish, or Swedish). The language selection only affects the user interface for your user and is remembered the next time you log in. You can also change the default language of the user interface for all users (see Preference - Administration).

title: Menu icons
body: Click to access the FA Documentation site.

title: Menu icons
body: Click to view what version of FA Back you are currently running and see the highlights of the latest major version released. Your current version number is in the title of the window that opens.

title: Menu icons
body: Click to log out of the FA system.

title: Add a column based on a key figure
body: You can add custom columns based on key figures into the different search views and Analytics+. To learn how to do this, follow the instructions below.

title: Add a column based on a key figure
body: If the key figure you want to add as an Analytics+ column isn't already in the system, configure it in Preference first. To learn how to add key figures, see Add key figures in FA User guide.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: You can add key figure values for contacts, portfolios, or securities by entering them manually in the respective windows or by importing them.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: To add key figure values manually in FA Back, do the following:

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Open the Key figures tab in the Contact, Portfolio, or Security window.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: On the left side of the tab, select the key figure and click Add new value.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Define the date and value.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Click Add.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: For more information about importing key figures, see File formats for importing securities and security prices and File formats for importing contacts and portfolios in FA Back reference.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: To configure a key figure as an Analytics+ column, do the following:

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Open Preference → Content and translations → Analytics+ columns.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Click Add new column and fill in the fields:

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select how you want to define the column - Select "Based on a security key figure".

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Code* - A unique code for the column. You can't change the code after saving.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Name* - Name for the column.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Description - Optional description of the column content, shown when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Link - Optional link for more information about the column, shown when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select the security key figure you want to use as a column - Choose the key figure to link to the column from the dropdown list.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select how to calculate values on group levels -

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Do you want to override the default formatting? Choose if you want to specify a custom formatting for the column. If you select "Yes, override formatting", you also need to specify the format.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Click Save.

title: Unlock contact's portfolios when LEI is entered
body: This rule removes the "LEI code missing" portfolio tag and unlocks the contact's portfolios if the contact has LEI code entered in the Contact window, MiFiR tab.

title: Unlock contact's portfolios when LEI is entered
body: Condition: LEI code is available in the contact

title: Unlock contact's portfolios when LEI is entered
body: Actions: The "LEI code missing" tag is removed from the portfolios where the contact is the primary contact, and the portfolios are unlocked.

title: API integrations
body: GraphiQL is a query tool available in FA Developer App. The tool can be used to define queries and mutations. It features a GraphQL editor, as well as documentation for the available GraphQL endpoints.

title: API integrations
body: GraphQL API provides many customization opportunities, for example:

title: API integrations
body: Building an integration between FA and an external application. A good example of this would be an integration between FA and your version of FA Client Portal.

title: API integrations
body: Building a custom JSReport (for details about custom reports, see the Reporting section). JSReports use GraphQL API to fetch the report data from FA Back.

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app

title: Import and modify data via mutation API
body: Import and modify data via mutation API

title: Overview
body: You can import or modify FA data via GraphQL mutation API. When you import an object (for example, a contact or a portfolio), you need to provide all required fields as a parameter. When modifying an object you need to give minimum information that is enough to identify the entity. Imported attributes are updated, the left out attributes keep their previous values.

title: Overview
body: To import or modify different object types, use the following endpoints:

title: Overview
body: Contacts => importContacts

title: Overview
body: Portfolios => importPortfolios

title: Overview
body: Securities => importSecurities

title: Overview
body: Transactions => importTransactions

title: Overview
body: Trade orders => importTradeOrders

title: Overview
body: Security prices => importPrices

title: Overview
body: You can adjust the import behavior by using importGeneral endpoint and specifying the import parameters as you need. The import parameters are listed below:

title: Overview
body: importGeneral:

title: Overview
body: rows : list of objects to import (mandatory)

title: Overview
body: withRules : boolean whether to run rules when importing (default = false)

title: Overview
body: importAsync : boolean whether to use asynchronous importing or not (default = false)

title: Overview
body: mode / sMode / pMode / prMode / trMode / oMode / cMode : option to control import behavior for all object types (mode) or specific object type (sMode / pMode / prMode / trMode / oMode / cMode). Available options are:

title: Overview
body: 0 - insert and update (default)

title: Overview
body: 1- insert only

title: Overview
body: 2 - update only

title: Overview
body: Each endpoint can be used to import or update one or many objects in one request. The response identifies if the request was successful or if it had errors (specified in the response).

title: Define the request
body: For a valid request such as below, you need to:

title: Define the request
body: Define the mutation endpoint to use.

title: Define the request
body: Define the request content as a list in the parameter, using the syntax from FA importing (see Importing in FA Back reference).

title: Define the request
body: Define the attributes without the prefix used in FA importing. For example, in FA importing, contact name is defined as "c.name", so in the mutation API, you need to define this attribute as "name".

title: Define the request
body: Define all required attributes in the request, as described in FA importing formats. In the request below, for example, the required fields for importing contacts are "Contact ID", "Name", "Type", "Juridical form", "Status", "Tax country", "Classification", and "Identity".

title: Define the request
Define the request
body: You can find an example of how to use importGeneral to control whether to run rules in Import data and trigger a business rule.

title: Interpret the response
body: The response structure is similar to the request. The result contains a list of map structures. Each item in the list presents an object that was imported. All attributes including the ones not explicitly used in the request are returned. The attributes are prefixed. For example, contact name is c.name. The success is indicated in the importStatus attribute with the OK value.

title: Interpret the response
body:
{
  "data": {
    "importContacts": [
      {
        "c.marketingCommunication": "",
        "c.subType": "",
        "c.language": "",
        "c.type": "1",
        "c.taxCountry": "FI",
        "c.externalId": "",
        "c.memo": "",
        "c.country": "",
        "c.phone2": "",
        "c.phone1": "",
        "c.juridical": "PE",
        "c.representatives": "*** ,",
        "c.fax": "",
        "c.email": "",
        "c.extContactIdList": "",
        "c.name": "GraphQL contact",
        "c.status": "A",
        "c.profileAttributes": "",
        "c.classification3": "",
        "c.contactExchanges": "",
        "importStatus": "OK",
        "c.electronicCommunication": "",
        "c.classification2": "",
        "c.transactionExtIdLevel": "1",
        "c.address1": "",
        "c.address2": "",
        "c.tags": "",
        "c.nationality": "",
        "c.city": "",
        "c.classification": "PROF",
        "c.contactId": "GQL1",
        "c.identity": "ID",

      },...
  ]
}

title: Interpret the response
body: If required attributes are missing or the code is incorrect, the importStatus attribute has the ERROR value. Each attribute with an error is marked with ERROR (ERROR:[ImportError.required] in case the required value is missing).

title: Basic info tab
body: The Basic info tab contains the basic information about the fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund company*

title: Basic info tab
body: The company the fund is administered by. See Create a fund company.

title: Basic info tab
body: Language*

title: Basic info tab
body: Language to use in portfolio reports. You can also see the language of the fund in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical*

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical form of the fund company. You can also see the juridical form in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund name.

title: Basic info tab
body: ID*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique fund ID used to identify the fund and search for funds. You should only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund business ID

title: Basic info tab
body: The ID provided by the authorities for your fund. Fund business ID is used for tax reporting purposes. The ID is saved in FA Back. You can find it in the Portfolio window, IDs tab.

title: Basic info tab
body: Inception date*

title: Basic info tab
body: The date when the fund starts.

title: Basic info tab
body: Currency*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund currency. Once you create a fund, the currency can't be changed.

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method*

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method for the fund portfolio:

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with separate items – Valuates portfolio with average price, but keeps track of original purchase dates.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO (combined) – Valuates the portfolio based directly on transactions in the subportfolios.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Portfolio type. Choose the type that corresponds to the fund portfolio.

title: Cash accounts
body: Cash accounts for the fund.

title: Cash accounts
body: Name*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account name.

title: Cash accounts
body: Currency*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account currency.

title: Cash accounts
body: Account number*

title: Cash accounts
body: The account number, for example, the bank account number.

title: Cash accounts
body: Set as default account

title: Cash accounts
body: Set the account as the default account of the portfolio. All transactions are by default created against this account.

title: Cash accounts
body: Set as fee capitalization account

title: Cash accounts
body: Set the account as the cash account for fee capitalization (see Set up a management fee and Set up a performance fee). You can only set one account for fee capitalization per fund.

title: Cash accounts
body: Share to all parent portfolio's subportfolios

title: Cash accounts
body: Make the account available in the parent portfolio and in the other portfolios under the parent portfolio. Choose this option, for example, if you are going to use FX-hedged share classes in your fund. For details, see Hedge currency exposure.

title: Interest details
body: To set up, track, and eventually capitalize account interest for a fund, you need to specify the account interest details in the Interest details section. You can track the accrued interest in the NAV overview. To capitalize the interest, you need to use FA Back (see Handle position and account interest).

title: Interest details
body: Define account interest using the following fields:

title: Interest details
body: Base instrument

title: Interest details
body: Security that determines the base interest rate. You can:

title: Interest details
body: Set a fixed or floating rate (for example, based on Euribor) by selecting an index security. To do this, you need to have a base security in FA Back which has the interest percentage specified in the Market data info tab of the Security window (see Market data info in FA Back reference).

title: Interest details
body: Set an indexed rate (for example, based on CPI). To do this, select an index security that has up-to-date interest rates in the Market data info tab of the Security window (see Market data info in FA Back reference).

title: Interest details
body: Offset days

title: Interest details
body: Number of days between observing the index value and using the index value to calculate accrued interest. For example, if you set offset days as 5, the system uses the index value observed on July 1st to calculate accrued interest on July 6th.

title: Interest details
body: Day count convention

title: Interest details
body: Number of days in a year. During the account interest calculation, the system uses the number of days to convert the annual interest rate into a daily interest rate.

title: Interest details
body: Transaction type

title: Interest details
body: Transaction type for the account interest calculation. Select "Interest (INT)".

title: Interest details
body: Click Edit spreads to define spreads based on the account balance:

title: Interest details
body: Date

title: Interest details
body: Date from which onwards the spread applies.

title: Interest details
body: Balance from / Balance to

title: Interest details
body: Optional lower and upper account balance thresholds at which the spread applies. If you add multiple spreads and want to apply a specific spread to all values below or above a certain account balance, you can leave the first Balance from and the last Balance to fields empty. To add or delete a spread, use the and buttons.

title: Interest details
body: Example: The account balance is 120 000€ and a fixed base rate is set at 2%. Spread is set at 2% for 0-50 000€, 3% for 50 000-110 000€, and 3,5% for 110 000-200 000€. The interest rate used in the formula is as follows: 4% on 0-49 999€, 5% on 50 000-109 999€, and 5,5% on 110 000-120 000€.

title: Interest details
body: Spread

title: Interest details
body: Additional interest rate on top of the base rate determined by the base security. Enter the spread as a number without the percent sign.

title: Handle position and account interest
body: You can use the FA system to calculate, track, and capitalize account interest for fund portfolio positions and cash accounts. The system calculates accrued interest every time you calculate NAV or fees if you set up a separate fee workflow (see Ongoing fees).

title: Handle position and account interest
body: The system uses the following formula to calculate accrued interest:

title: Handle position and account interest
body: Accrued interest

title: Handle position and account interest
body: Account balance

title: Handle position and account interest
body: Base interest rate

title: Handle position and account interest
body: spread

title: Handle position and account interest
body: Number of days in a year

title: Handle position and account interest
body: In this formula, account balance is the balance at the beginning of the day, base interest rate is determined by an index or a fixed or floating rate, and spread is interest on top of the base rate that you can specify depending on the account balance.

title: Handle position and account interest
body: The following sections describe how the system calculates interest for fund portfolio holdings and how you can set up and capitalize account interest for fund cash accounts.

title: Calculate accrued interest on fund portfolio positions
body: Accrued interest on the fund portfolio holdings is calculated automatically based on the fixings information entered for securities in FA Back. To learn more, see Bonds in FA User guide.

title: Calculate accrued interest on fund portfolio positions
body: You can track the accrual for fund portfolio holdings in the NAV overview in the "Accrued interest" row (see View and check NAV calculation).

title: Set up account interest
body: To set up account interest for a fund, you need to specify the account interest details by doing the following:

title: Set up account interest
body: In the NAV status view, click on the fund to open the side pane and then open the Fund wizard by clicking the icon.

title: Set up account interest
body: In the Basic info tab, select a cash account, click on Interest details, and fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Interest details.

title: Set up account interest
body: Click Save.

title: Set up account interest
body: The system now starts accruing interest on the account. You can track the accrual in the NAV overview in the "Accrued account interest" row (see View and check NAV calculation).

title: Capitalize accrued account interest in FA Back
body: To capitalize the interest accrued by fund investments, follow the instructions in steps 2 and 3 in Set up and run account interest (FA User guide). You can skip step 1 because fund account interest is already set up.

title: Capitalize accrued account interest in FA Back
body: The system creates the capitalization transaction when you execute the account interest run. You can also schedule the run for later.

title: View fund orders
body: The Orders view shows information about trade orders for funds. You can create, edit, and execute fund orders in FA Back. Fund orders can be executed manually in FA Back or via automatic order execution for funds so that incoming trade orders with Executable status are executed when you accept NAV (see Create a fund).

title: View the list of orders
body: You can view the fund orders as a list and filter them by any column (for example, share class and status). You can choose a predefined transaction date period (today, previous 7 days, current month, previous month, current quarter, previous quarter) or select specific dates.

title: View the list of orders
body: You can save your filter settings by clicking . To open the saved view again, select it in the Saved views field. You can manage saved views by clicking .

title: View order details
body: To view details for a fund order, click on a row in the list. In the side pane that opens, you can see the following information:

title: View order details
body: Fund order details: Shows the same information as the fund order list columns and the fund order execution method and reference.

title: View order details
body: Documents: Shows documents uploaded for the order, the tags applied to them, and the date and time they were last modified. You can download the documents to your computer.

title: Order information
body: Account

title: Order information
body: The fund or share account to record deposits and withdrawals. The default account used in trade orders is specified in the fund and share class settings

title: Order information
body: Cashflow (client)

title: Order information
body: The trade amount from the client's perspective. The amount on each row is summed up into a total amount shown in the last row.

title: Order information
body: Cashflow (fund)

title: Order information
body: The trade amount from the perspective of the fund. The amount on each row is summed up into a total amount shown in the last row.

title: Order information
body: Code

title: Order information

title: Order information
body: Cost 1 and 2

title: Order information
body: The cost amount.

title: Order information
body: Cost type 1 and 2

title: Order information
body: The cost types from the alternatives defined in the cost type preferences. The cost can be, for example, a credit fee or a transaction fee (see Transaction fees for a fund).

title: Order information
body: Created

title: Order information
body: The date and time when the fund order was created.

title: Order information
body: Description on statement

title: Order information
body: A description for the transactions and counter transactions that are created from the fund order.

title: Order information
body: Execution method

title: Order information
body: The fund order execution method. For more information about execution methods, see Trade order window in FA Back reference.

title: Order information
body: External ID

title: Order information
body: The external ID of the fund order.

title: Order information
body: Gross trade amount

title: Order information
body: The trade amount excluding costs.

title: Order information
body: ID

title: Order information
body: The database ID of the fund order in the FA system.

title: Order information
body: Internal info

title: Order information
body: A description of the transaction created by the fund order.

title: Order information
body: ISIN

title: Order information
body: The share class ISIN.

title: Order information
body: Net trade amount

title: Order information
body: The trade amount including costs.

title: Order information
body: Payment date

title: Order information
body: The payment date of the order when the payment date is different from the settlement date.

title: Order information
body: Portfolio

title: Order information
body: The name of the shareholder's portfolio.

title: Order information
body: Receive date

title: Order information
body: The date when the fund order information was received from the client.

title: Order information
body: Receive time

title: Order information
body: The time when the fund order information was received from the client.

title: Order information
body: Report FX rate

title: Order information
body: The report exchange rate or the exchange rate between the share class security currency and the shareholder portfolio currency.

title: Order information
body: Security currency

title: Order information

title: Order information
body: Settlement date

title: Order information
body: The settlement date of the fund order (see Trade order window in FA Back reference).

title: Order information
body: Share class

title: Order information
body: The share class name.

title: Order information
body: Status

title: Order information
body: The status of the fund order. The status options are: Open, Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market, Settled in the market, Executed, Cancelled, Rejected, and Expired.

title: Order information
body: Tags

title: Order information
body: The tags applied to the fund order. Tags can be used to sort trade orders or adjust the trade order workflow.

title: Order information
body: Tax 1 and 2

title: Order information
body: The tax amount in the transaction. For subscriptions, taxes add the trade amount, and for redemptions, taxes reduce the trade amount.

title: Order information
body: Tax type 1 and 2

title: Order information
body: The tax types from the alternatives defined in Preference (see Preference - Taxation in FA Back reference).

title: Order information
body: Trade time

title: Order information
body: The time of the trade.

title: Order information
body: Transaction date

title: Order information
body: The transaction date. Transaction date determines when the transaction took effect.

title: Order information
body: Transaction type

title: Order information
body: Transaction type (subscription or redemption).

title: Order information
body: Unit price

title: Order information
body: Preliminary estimation of the order unit price. When the trade order is executed, the system determines the unit price based on recent NAV acceptance.

title: Order information
body: Units

title: Order information
body: Preliminary number of units in the fund order. When the trade order is executed, the actual number of units is determined.

title: Pay out fund dividends
body: FA allows you to run dividends for a fund and create dividend transactions via a corporate action. You can view the dividend history in the Dividends view and refresh the list with the button.

title: Pay out fund dividends
body: To enable dividend payments for a fund share class, open the Share class wizard, Basic info tab and select the Enable dividend payments option (see Add share classes).

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: To calculate dividends and create dividend transactions in the shareholder portfolios, follow the steps:

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Open the Dividends view.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Click Add dividend in the top-right corner of the view and fill in the fields:

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Fund

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: The fund that pays the dividend.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Share class

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: The share class that pays the dividend.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Declaration date

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: The date when the dividend payment is announced.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Ex-date

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: The dividend ex-date. The dividend is calculated based on the number of share class units in the shareholder's portfolio on the morning of the ex-date (the position after the previous day's transactions). This date will become the transaction date of the created dividend transaction. When you calculate NAV on the ex-date, the dividend isn't anymore included in NAV.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Payment date

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: The payment date of the dividend, when the dividend is actually paid to the shareholder. Payment date becomes the settlement date of the created dividend transaction.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Dividend per unit

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: The dividend to pay per share class unit.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Transaction type

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Transaction type to use for the dividend transactions. By default, FA Fund Management uses the Fund dividend (FMDIV) transaction type.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Memo

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Memo note for the dividend.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: If the dividend execution date is today, proceed to executing the dividend by clicking Save and execute.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Alternatively, save the dividend and execute it later (click Execute in the Dividends view).

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Check the tax rates and FX rate in the Dividend view that opens. Click Execute to generate dividend transactions. The dividend status changes to "Executing", and then to "Executed" in the Dividends view. You can view the dividend transactions by double-clicking the dividend.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: As a result, FA Fund management does the following:

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Creates dividend transactions in the shareholder portfolios.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: Creates a cashout transaction (FMDWD type) to take out the dividend amount from the fund portfolio. Next time you calculate NAV, the total dividend amount is excluded from the calculation.

title: Create and execute a dividend
body: You can ensure that all shareholders received dividends by clicking Reconcile in the Dividends view. The system shows a confirmation message that reads "Dividend transactions are created for all shareholders".

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: You can edit an unexecuted dividend by doing the following:

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: For the dividend you want to modify, click the icon and select Edit.

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: Make your changes in the side pane that opens.

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: If you want to proceed to executing the dividend, click Save and execute and fill in the tax rates and FX rate. If you want to execute the dividend later, click Save.

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: You can cancel dividend transactions for executed dividends, for example, if you notice that some tax rates are incorrect or if the error is due to incorrect positions in shareholder portfolios. To cancel dividend transactions, do the following:

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: Double-click an executed dividend in the list.

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: Select the dividend transactions to delete and click the  icon.

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: If needed, make corrections in the shareholders' portfolios.

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: Click Reconcile next to the dividend in the Dividends view and confirm that you want to execute missing transactions (Execute).

title: Edit dividends or dividend transactions
body: Enter the correct dividend parameters (you can only correct tax or exchange rates that are not used in any transactions) and click Execute.
